story.text: Hey, what grade are you in?
Fourth grade!
Do you like the fourth-grade?
<label>Yeah!</label> Wanna meet my classmates?
I mean, I guess…
OK! Here they are!
Wow. Thanks, kid. Mind if I ask your class a question?
Sure! But hurry up. Recess starts soon.

Who here feels like you <label>belong at the school</label>?


So, like, feeling respected by other students and supported by adults?
Those of us in <label>yellow</label> feel like we belong. Why do you ask?

Well, feeling like you belong at school is [really important](https://www.edweek.org/leadership/a-universal-prevention-measure-that-boosts-attendance-and-improves-behavior/2024/04). It helps you feel better and do well in school.
Can we go to recess now?
Sure. I’m gonna visit the next classroom over: Fifth graders.
Sup. Who *are* you?

That’s a complicated question.


Fifth-graders, who here feels like you belong in school?
Most of us, obviously.
OK, I have some more…
WE’RE BACK FROM RECESS!!!!!!
I have some more questions.
OKAYYYYUHH!!!!
Who here has a good <label>relationship with their teachers</label>?
Most of them say they have <label>supportive relationships</label> in their lives—teachers, family members, and friends.

But they’re kids—so they have some complaints.


Most fourth- and fifth-graders say they aren’t <label>engaged in school</label>. They aren’t excited or interested in class.

Many say their <label>school’s climate</label> isn’t ideal. 


They say the teachers aren’t always excited to be there, the school building isn’t great, and the rules aren’t fair (or so they say).

But overall, most fourth- and fifth-graders are doing pretty well.


They said they frequently experienced <label>positive feelings</label> in the past week — excitement, happiness, hope, love, and safety.
But for fifth-graders, their lives are about to shift dramatically.

In one year, these fifth-graders will experience a new era of their development. Their brains will become more malleable, like a block of clay softening to be resculpted. Scientists call this “brain plasticity.” The first period of brain plasticity is from ages 0 to 3, when our brains [grow rapidly](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK234146/). We create new billions of brain cells and neural connections. But this second period of plasticity, between 11 and 14, is when our neural connections are reorganized, writes developmental psychologist Laurence Steinberg in his book "[Age of Opportunity.](https://www.laurencesteinberg.com/books/age-of-opportunity)" **>> Timeline: 0 to 3 + 11 to 14** The brain reorganization happens because our brains become highly sensitive to what we experience, both good and bad. One experience that is [especially heightened](https://www.nature.com/articles/nature25770) is social interactions. Steinberg writes that, during this period, we are more sensitive to social acceptance and rejection. So hanging out with friends *feels* better than it does at other points in our lives, while being rejected or bullied feels worse. These experiences rewire our brains; some neural connections get stronger, while others are pruned. **>> Diagram** Meanwhile, their brains will also develop a greater capacity for [self-direction](https://nap.nationalacademies.org/catalog/25388/the-promise-of-adolescence-realizing-opportunity-for-all-youth). So they’ll want more autonomy on what to wear, what to say, and how to spend their time.
But in one year, many of these fifth-graders will also be forced to change schools…
… and be merged with students from other schools in something called “middle school,” which serves grades 6 to 8.

Being around so many new peers—and older students—will throw their social lives into disarray. They’ll no longer have one dedicated teacher, but rather a different teacher for each subject. And they’ll feel like they have less autonomy. There will be no recess. They’ll be required to switch classes on an unyielding schedule. And they’ll only have short breaks to do what they desperately want—and need—to do: socialize.

This is how much fifth-graders feel like they <label>belong in their school</label>.


What do sixth-graders say?
Whoa. Sixth-graders are way less likely to feel .
And seventh-graders feel even less like they <label>belong in their school</label>.
The portion of students who are <label>engaged in school</label> also plummets after fifth grade..
Their <label>relationship with teachers</label> gets significantly worse. Many say they don’t feel like their teachers care about them or respect them.

Most feel like their <label>school climate</label> isn’t ideal.


They believe their teachers are less excited; the physical space is less pleasant; and the rules are unfair.
Luckily, most students still say they have <label>supportive relationships</label>. But that support is usually family or friends, and no longer adults at school.
Ultimately, fewer students say they frequently experienced <label>positive feelings</label> in the past week.
If kids hate middle school so much, why does it exist?

Around 1900, most school districts had one school for kindergarten to 8th grade. But everyone from [college presidents](https://www.tojned.net/journals/tojned/articles/v04i01/v04i01-01.pdf) to the [National Education Association](https://www.rand.org/pubs/monographs/MG139.html) argued that seventh graders should be attend a school that prepares them for high school: junior high school.


**>> Diagram**


However, what really pushed school districts to adopt junior high schools was overcrowding. Industrialization and immigration brought a huge influx of families to urban areas, crowding K-8 schools, according to a [RAND book](https://www.rand.org/pubs/monographs/MG139.html) on middle schools. So taking the older kids and putting them in junior high made practical sense. During this era, the number of junior highs skyrocketed.


**>> Chart | Need data (rise of junior highs)**


Junior high was [basically](https://archive.org/details/educatingyoungad0000unse_q0p1/page/36/mode/2up?q=Mounting+Dissatisfaction) high school for younger kids, so in the 1960s [education scholars](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/19404476.2016.1165036) wanted to replace junior highs with something that caters to the specific needs of this age group. They wanted smaller group learning, better relationships with teachers, and more exploration. They called it middle school.


Slowly, more and more districts adopted the middle school model.


**>> Chart | [NCES](https://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d10/tables/dt10_097.asp)**
After middle school, things stay pretty much the same as they transition to high school.
In high school, <label>school engagement</label> falls even further.
Very few students have strong <label>relationships with teachers</label>.
And their <label>sense of belonging</label> stays low.

So, should we get rid of middle schools?


Research out of [New York](https://www.educationnext.org/stuck-in-the-middle/), [Florida](https://www.educationnext.org/the-middle-school-plunge/), and [several other](https://ies.ed.gov/ncee/edlabs/regions/west/Ask/Details/53) areas found that kids who attend middle schools learned less, while feeling lower levels of belonging and self esteem, when compared to kids who attend K-8 schools. This pushed some school districts to go back to the K-8 model. 


**>> Chart of some research**


But [other research](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0094119018300081) showed that kids in K-5 elementary schools actually do better because they’re not mixed with older kids, and that [makes up](https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.1086/498996) for the learning they lose in middle school.


**>> Chart of above research**


So there isn’t a clear answer for whether we should get rid of middle schools. Most education scholars now say that districts should do what is best for their students, based on their unique circumstances. Of course, funding still drives a lot of school decision-making; it’s chaotic and expensive to create new schools or remove ones that don’t work. So, more often than not, school districts prefer the status quo—and for most, it’s middle schools.

I’ve told many adults I’m working on a story about middle school. Almost immediately, they respond with, “Middle school sucked!”


And then they tell me how much better things got in high school.

We often treat middle schoolers as mid-evolution—no longer children, and waiting to be teens. We talk about it like it’s a phase to grow out of.


But brain science is showing us that it’s not a “phase”; it’s literally their brains doing exactly what they need to be doing to survive—and to grow.


“Adolescent brains are not simply ‘advanced’ child brains or ‘immature’ adult brains, but have evolved to meet the needs of this stage of life,” researchers wrote in the [National Academy of Sciences book](https://nap.nationalacademies.org/catalog/25388/the-promise-of-adolescence-realizing-opportunity-for-all-youth).

We’re learning that middle school has a huge effect on the rest of our lives. After all, it’s the period of our lives when our brains open up to the world—to feel more happiness, more sadness, more everything. The world we curate around middle-school kids shapes who they’ll become.


But maybe even that should take a back seat to what middle-schoolers are telling us: This isn’t working for us.

In a year, their brains will start caring way more about social interactions — exactly when they’re funneled off to a new school with new peers.


And they’ll also crave more autonomy — exactly when they’re shipped off to a bigger school with strict rules.
